answers: Ocarina of Time. Most players found having to pause in order to equip the iron boots required for this level to be too cumbersome. ANSWER: Water Temple
parts: Name this difficult dungeon from Legend of Zeld
This is the name given to the playable character in the Legend of Zelda series; in some games the player can change the name of this Hylian, who wears a green tunic.

This goddess in the Legend of Zelda series is the goddess of power. In The Wind Waker, the first Goddess Pearl that Link recovers from Dragon Roost Island belongs to this goddess, and in Ocarina of Time, Link can gain the ability to cast “[this goddess’s] Fire.”

answers: Dance [or Dance II; or La Danse]
parts: Give this title of two primitivist paintings of figures holding hands in a circle against a flat blue background, with one located in The Hermitage and a paler version at the Museum of Modern Art.
This French neo-Impressionist artist of La Danse spearheaded the style of fauvism (“FO-vism”) along with Andre Derain (“duh-RAN”) in the early 1900s.

Matisse’s Dance II was painted at this man’s request to “paint … as if you were painting for yourself.” He names an American museum whose current collection includes that painting and Matisse’s The Joy of Life.
Name this element with atomic number 16. In elemental form, 8 atoms of this element form a ring-shaped molecule.
This common sulfur-containing reagent with formula C2H6SO is a mild oxidant and may be used alongside oxalyl chloride in the Swern oxidation. It’s also a common drug delivery vehicle.
Sulfoxides such as DMSO may be oxidized further into one of these functional groups in which a sulfur is bonded to two oxygens.

answers: Marie-Jean-Antoine-Nicolas de Caritat, Marquis de Condorcet
parts: Identify this philosophical work better known for its merciless attacks on organized religions, particularly Christianity, and its advocacy of Deism. This work argues that Christians practice a “religious denial of God,” and that for God to pay attention only to Earth would cheapen his power.
The Age of Reason was written by this American thinker, who defended the French Revolution against Edmund Burke in his earlier book Rights of Man. He also wrote the pamphlet Common Sense.

Paine was a friend and one-time collaborator of this philosopher and expert on voting theory, whose own works include his essay advocating for gender equality, “On Giving Women the Right of Citizenship.”

answers: bars [or saloons; prompt on restaurants or cafes, since it is the End of the Line Cafe]
parts: Name this play set in Reading, Pennsylvania, during the closing of Olstead's steel mill. During this play Cynthia and Tracey compete for a job while the mill attempts to hire non-union workers.
This author of Sweat and Ruined dramatized the life of her seamstress great-grandmother in Intimate Apparel.

Sweat is largely set in one of these places, and Mama Nadi runs one of them which doubles as a brothel in Ruined. In O’Neill’s The Iceman Cometh, the ex-alcoholic Theodore Hickman comes to one of these places.
Name this city, that along with Anshan, served as the center of Elamite civilization. Gustave Jéquier discovered the Code of Hammurabi stele in this city while excavating in 1901.
Susa contains the tomb of this Biblical figure, who interprets Nebuchadnezzar’s dreams and survives a den of lions in his namesake book.
Susa lost significance during the Sassanid period, when Shapur I built this nearby city which hosted a prominent academy.
The goddess Hera honored her slain servant Argus by placing his one hundred eyes on the tail of this ostentatious bird, which became one of her symbols.
Before being crushed by pine trees and turning into a bird, the gender-switching hero Caeneus fought as part of this Greek tribe that battled with the centaurs.

An Amazonian shrine of this god was protected by birds that seemed badass because they could shoot arrow-like feathers, but they were easily scared off by a bunch of Argonauts banging their weapons together.

Name this Zurich institution founded by Emmy Hennings and Hugo Ball, who recited the nonsense sound poem "Karawane" there while wearing a cylindrical cardboard "magical bishop" costume and a chef's hat.
The Cabaret Voltaire was frequented by artists in this absurdity-emphasizing movement founded in Switzerland. This movement included writers and artists like Hans Arp and Marcel Duchamp.
The Cabaret Voltaire was frequented by this author of the epic poem “The Approximate Man,” who featured dialogue between Mouth, Ear, Eye, Nose, Neck, and Eyebrow in The Gas Heart.

answers: compactification [prompt on descriptive answers like “curling up space”]
parts: Name these theories whose goal is to explain the strong, weak, and electromagnetic forces - but not gravity - as low-energy manifestations of a single underlying force.

M-theory is one proposal that attempts to unify all four fundamental forces together using these one-dimensional vibrating objects. Branes are a generalization of these objects to dimensions higher than one.

This term describes the task of reducing 10-dimensional string theory into everyday 4-dimensional spacetime so it reproduces ordinary observable physical phenomena. Early string theories focused on doing this to heterotic strings on Calabi-Yau manifolds.
Name this country where Gyanendra came to the throne after his nephew Crown Prince Dipendra killed the king and most of the royal family at a dinner party in Narayanhiti Palace in 2006.
From his base in this kingdom, Prithvi Narayan Shah subdued a Newar confederacy in the Kathmandu Valley and united Nepal under the Shah dynasty in 1768.

The Nepalese royal massacre occurred in the midst of civil war against anti-monarchy insurgents named for this Chinese communist who wrote a textbook on guerrilla warfare and recorded pithy sayings in his Little Red Book.

answers: trehalose [or mycose or tremalose; if someone asks, maltose has a different linkage]
parts: These eight-legged creatures are best known for being able to withstand extreme temperatures, pressures, and radiation, allowing them to survive briefly in outer space. They are colloquially called water bears.
Tardigrades can enter a state of cryptobiosis, in which their metabolic processes almost stop. While in that state, they use this sugar, which consists of two glucose molecules with a 1-1 linkage.
Like birds, female tardigrades have one of these structure, an opening that has both digestive, urinary, and reproductive functions.
Identify this god of death and son Surya whose sister is a river deity with a similar name. He is depicted leading souls to naraka upon death.
Hindus may wash coins to pay reverence to Lakshmi, the goddess of wealth, on the first day of this Hindu holiday of lights.
While temple coins often features images of Rama, some from Bengal may feature Krishna on the obverse with this leader of the Gopis Krishna’s lover, but not his wife.
Name this post-Civil War period of military occupation in the South criticized for its civil rights progress by the Dunning School of history.

This supporter of Charles Beard demonstrated that Jim Crow was a 19th-century innovation rather than a perpetual way of life in The Strange Career of Jim Crow. This historian incorporated economic forces into his analysis in The Origins of the New South.

This scholar pushed back against the Dunning School interpretation in his book, Black Reconstruction in America. This sociologist studied African-Americans in the city’s 7th Ward in The Philadelphia Negro.
Name this author of the Ibis Trilogy and The Calcutta Chromosome.

The Calcutta Chromosome revolves around mysticism-inspired work by a character with this occupation, the real-life Ronald Ross. Mr. Kapasi works as an interpreter for one of these people in a Jhumpa Lahiri story.
Bahram Modi sells this substance in River of Smoke, and the Ibis Trilogy is set during the beginning of conflicts over this resource. Thomas de Quincy wrote a memoir about his use of this substance.

answers: William Byrd (The older composer is Thomas Tallis.)
parts: Name this Catholic English composer, who co-composed a set of Cantiones Sacrae along with an older composer who may have been his teacher. Along with that older composer, he held a monopoly on printing music for 21 years.

Like much Renaissance music, Byrd’s motet Aspice Domine de sede (“AH-spee-che do-mee-ne”) is a polyphonic piece based around one of these pre-existing melodies, known by a Latin term. These melodies were usually placed in the tenor voice.

This English queen granted Byrd and Tallis the monopoly on music printing, and was the dedicatee of their Cantiones Sacrae. Although she was a Protestant, she kept Byrd around in order to raise her court’s reputation.

answers: eating babies [accept eating children or cannibalism or clear equivalents]
parts: Name this essay describing a fight between the Ancients and the Moderns, with gaps in the manuscript making it unclear who won. It is interrupted by a long description of a bee wrecking a spider's web.

Description acceptable. The author of "The Battle of the Books" suggested in another essay taking this specific action to alleviate poverty in Ireland. That essay claims this action would help lessen the number of Papists and provide glove material.
That essay, "A Modest Proposal," and "The Battle of the Books" were written by this author of Gulliver's Travels.

answers: intuition [accept word forms; prompt on the gut or obvious equivalents]
parts: Name this writer of several of the most frequently assigned psychology textbooks, including Exploring Psychology and Social Psychology.

Specific term required. The most highly cited academic paper of Myers found that this emotion is correlated with relationship closeness and religiosity, but not necessarily income. Uniquely among nations, Bhutan calculates this emotion's "gross national" form as a proxy for societal well-being.

Myers also wrote a book about the "powers and perils" of trusting this faculty. Jonathan Haidt argued that the roots of moral reasoning lie in this faculty, and its primacy in decision-making is explored by Malcolm Gladwell's pop psychology book Blink.
Name this pop group. Geri (“JERRY”) Haliwell wore an iconic Union Jack dress during this group’s performance of “Who Do You Think You Are” at the 1997 Brit Awards.
Halliwell’s Union Jack dress and Noel Gallagher’s Union Jack guitar symbolized this punningly-named cultural resurgence of the ‘90s associated with Britpop.
The Spice Girls and earlier groups led the “Second British Invasion” of music in the United States. The First British Invasion began when this boy band performed on The Ed Sullivan Show.
The language SQL is used to manipulate these large collections of information, which organize entries into rows and columns.
This operation is used to combine two tables in a relational database. It exists in inner, outer, and cross varieties, and requires the two tables to share one column with the same label.
In SQL, this statement is used to reverse all changes made to the database since the last START TRANSACTION.

answers: Der Ring des Nibelungen [or The Ring of the Nibelungs or the Ring cycle]
parts: Name this cycle of four operas by Richard Wagner, which tells the story of the deeds of Siegfried and the gods’ attempts to win the title cursed object. Its first two entries are Das Rheingold and Die Walküre (“vahl-kuu-ruh”).

The first complete performance of the Ring cycle took place at the Festspielhaus in this German city. It still hosts an annual festival devoted to Wagner, with customers often waiting over eight years to get tickets.

This Swedish soprano, celebrated for her tremendous power and stamina, was considered the world’s leading Brünnhilde during the 50s and 60s. She sang the role under Georg Solti in the first-ever complete recording of the Ring cycle.
